title: Relative Clauses All 4
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2, B1whoB2, B1whomB2, B1nothingB2 or B1whatB2.

sentence: Could you tell me what's wrong with
explain: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.

sentence: The boss would like to fire the guy
explain: Corr: who, whom or that. We refer to a person, so we cannot use 'which'. The relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause, so we can use the objective case of 'who' that is 'whom'. But 'who' is acceptable, too, just like 'that'.

sentence: First, we saw a church beside
explain: Corr: which. We refer back to a noun (a church), so we cannot use 'what'. There's a preposition, so only 'which' is correct here and we cannot leave it out.
Corr: which. We refer back to a noun (a graveyard), so we cannot use 'what'. There's a preposition, so only 'which' is correct here and we cannot leave it out.

sentence: Why do you direct all the phone calls
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer back to a noun (phone calls), so we cannot use 'what'. As the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we can leave it out. If we choose to include it, 'that' is the preferred solution because there's 'all' in the sentence.

sentence: Yes, my hair is graying. However, this is something over
explain: Corr: which. We refer back to a noun (something), so we cannot use 'what'. There's a preposition (over), so we cannot leave out the relative pronoun and 'that' wouldn't be correct because it cannot be used after prepositions.
Corr: that or which. It's an 'it's ... that' structure, so we cannot use 'what' here and 'that' is preferred to 'which'. We cannot leave it out because it's the subject of the relative clause.
